posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Hello, I am a recent alum from FRC , and finding motors outside of first that have any reasonable amount of power seems like a whole can of worms with industrial motors being rediculously expensive, and hobby motors having little support. I am doing research at my university, and I’m wondering if anyone has reputable motor supplier suggestions they can really range in price, just wondering if mentors have suggestions as to where to even start looking! Thank you!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
It depends a ton on what power rating you want to use.

By the way: You CAN use FRC motors in industry. Anybody who tells you you can’t probably works in a highly regulated or specialized industry.

So, with that out of the way: Price and power ranges? I might have some ideas. (I like cheap motors, as does my boss.)

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: RC motors (cars, drones, planes, or boats) are the general source of hobby-grade motors and controllers. Both brushed and (increasingly now) brushless. There’s a wide range of sizes, power outputs, and voltage inputs available, and you should be able to find something in the right ballpark for most reasonably sized projects (with exceptions as you get towards either extreme in the size ranges). They won’t have the feature-rich “smart motion” controllers you’re used to in FRC , but that is a market that’s pretty much built up specifically for FRC (and the closest you’ll find in that spectrum is in industrial servo motors, which are a whole different tax bracket).

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Looking for at the minimum 2 nm continuous torque, that could be geared, it seems like hobby motors have relatively high rpm, while industrial motors tend to have lower, making the hobby motors so much more advantageous because they can be geared down. The output shaft after gearing will likely only need to run around 120 rpm if that, and have 30+ nm of torque at that point. I’ll need at least 4 motors, and we’d like to spend less than $2000, have some standardized communication protocal - like CAN or CAN FD, something propriotary would be ok, and NEEDS a software API in python or C++

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Henry_Mahnke:

industrial motors … expensive, and hobby motors having little support

This is a good observation.  Based on it, you might reasonably infer that a significant portion of a motor’s cost is associated with support.  And you’d be right.  Industrial motors are expensive, not because their materials and production processes are, but because they are expected to be durable, reliable, safe, serviceable, and available.  Keeping a plant running requires all of that.

By comparison, hobby motors are cheap.

What will the motors in your research project need to do?

—-

What is your supply voltage?

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked:
We are making a test bed for a Cable Driven Parallel Robot (CDPR), It will scale to a 40ft x 40ft x 40ft robot, but validating winch designs, pulleys, frame, and porting code from Matlab-Simulink from our last test project that used a horrible system of a series of analog to digital input output devices to make Simulink work with motors. The fully scaled version will feature a maximum payload of 1000 ish kg with the help of a crane (max speed of 0.1 m/s, so fast, I know ) , and we have funding secured for all of the hardware for that, just scraping together money and making a test bed so we can hit the ground running when that projects starts later this year. We currently use Odrive motors, and while I am remote over the summer, other lab researchers have had difficulty getting CAN working on the motors, and have less experience working with Motor API’s so I’ve been trying to diagnose issues over zoom calls, which is more difficult on the wiring end.

Preferably using DC brushless motors for this project, 120V max, and preferably all the motors could run on the same circuit

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
I’d start at:

Manufacturer and Supplier for Stepper Motor, Brushless DC Motor, DC Motor, AC Motors, Planetary Gearbox, Linear Actuator, Drivers and Controllers

If you’re able to stretch the budget a bit, these guys are based in MN and have decent prices (for industrial-grade motors with gearboxes and encoders and all that good stuff). https://midwestmotion.com/

link_counts.title: Anaheim Automation - Your source for Stepper Motor, Brushless DC Motor, DC Motor, and Planetary Gearbox Products

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Depending on what exactly you need the motors to do, TalonFX with Phoenix 6 is an option. We have Python/C++ non- FRC support for Linux/Windows with practically identical API to what you use in FRC .

Phoenix 6 is fully supported outside of FRC on supported systems with a USB to CAN adapter. Installation: API Installation: C++ (Linux) Phoenix 6 is distributed through our APT repository. Begin wi...

You’re always welcome to shoot an email to our support if you’ve got any questions or run into difficulty setting up.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: You might consider Teknic CleaPath motors, potentially the SC series if you want to do lots of software things with them.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
I’ve worked with them before. Their cheapest brushed and brushless controllers can be used to drive generic motors (brushless you need to know your number of poles). They are able to be driven via PLC or Arduino with relative ease. However don’t expect FRC level of speed adjustment in a hurry. The controllers by default have a capacitor that limits the time for it to register a speed change and the default minimum is 500ms. For driving a two wheeled robot on the ground trying to follow a line this wasn’t going to work at all. Removing that cap will void warranty…

There is 0 intelligence in the controller for speed control (unless you only use halls due to a lack of encoder input) so it is up to you to close the loop with real encoder feedback.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Have you looked into stepper motors, hybrid steppers, or clearpath servos? They also have high voltage DC and AC servos from China on Amazon or AliExpress.

I would not use an FRC -grade motor for this. They’re not rated for continuous usage at any rated power, so you’d be guessing how much load you can put on them before they smoke. Better to use something actually rated for industrial use. The featureset is very different.

Examples: 400W 110V 1.3 Nm servo with brake: https://a.aliexpress.com/_mrbDEBq

Hybrid steppers: https://a.aliexpress.com/_mqrcD1e

Clearpath servos: https://teknic.com/model-info/CPM-MCPV-2311S-RLN/?model_voltage=75VDC

There’s a bunch of EtherCAT servos as well for cheap on AliExpress (< $250 per kit) but they’re 220V so you’d need a transformer. I wouldn’t count that out though. I often look at aliexpress first, then check eBay or Amazon for the same keywords once I know what I’m looking for.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Lots of good motor advice in here from those far more knowledgeable than myself.

Is the use of electric motors a design requirement in this situation (or highly preferred)? When scaled up to full size: High torque low speed and an agricultural background immediately leads me to hydraulic motors and a seperate pump, but that is a completely different system with massively different controls, safety, and other challenges.

For a prototype or other small scale application motors make a ton of sense over a hydraulic system.

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked:
We are looking at clearpath motors, but due to the need for torque control, or position control, and the necessity to follow a trajectory, the software must be really built out. Being familiar with FRC I thought these things were a given, but after experimenting with a clearpath motor, it doesn’t seem like this trajectory following is built in. Would have to do some kind of velocity commanding to the motor with a position feedback controller. Though they specifically recommend against it. We would like to use tension(torque) control with a position feedback controller, but with our clearpath motors we don’t even have the option to control the torque directly.

Still looking for motor companies that have a feature rich software library that allows this type of functionality.

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: For our initial prototype yes, electric motors are a design requirement, though I hadn’t though of using hydraulics and it does present a load of interesting functionality. We have never worked with hydraulics in my lab and there is a lot more to be careful of, so I’d assume we’d stick to electric motors. But thank you very much for the suggestion.

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Have you used their controllers before? It looks like they may be pretty feature rich, at least at a glance, but wondering if you have any personal insight! Thank you!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: I have not.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I didn’t realize the clearpath was so limited. If you want something more low level, Odrive is probably your best bet. Clearpath does support constant torque modes, but it looks like it can’t combo that with position control.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Odrive you can choose between several modes and while in the position loop it also uses the velocity and current loops. They had a great explainer for it in their docs.

When the control mode is set to position control, the whole loop runs. When running in velocity control mode, the position control part is removed and the velocity command is fed directly in to the second stage input. In torque control mode, only the current controller is used.

https://docs.odriverobotics.com/v/0.5.4/control.html

Their actual high level control modes do offer a decent variety

https://docs.odriverobotics.com/v/0.5.4/control-modes.html

link_counts.title: Control Structure and Tuning — ODrive Documentation 0.5.4 documentation

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Yeah Odrive has been great, but doesn’t lend itself to more industrial settings as we seek to build bigger robots with more capabilities, the odrive software functionality is exactly what we want, just in an industrial package.
